title: Tuning In to Source’s Signal on the Mountain
summary: Three seekers pause on a misty mountainside beneath a soaring cable car, tuning into the vibration of Source. A wildflower’s earthy whisper reveals our inner being as an ever-on channel—proof we’re never separate, always aligned with boundless intelligence.
principle: You can't be separated from Source.
story:
Javier stepped onto the grassy slope below the TelefériQo cable car station, the crisp mountain air of Pichincha filling his lungs. As a telecommunications engineer, he was accustomed to connecting antennas and fiber-optic cables, yet he’d never felt such a powerful signal as the one humming through his own chest.

Marisol joined him, her silver-streaked hair catching the morning sun. She had come seeking relief from a restless mind—an ache for purpose that no workshop or seminar could soothe. Together they watched the dome of Quito spread below, its tiled rooftops shimmering like a circuit board.

“I’ve been chasing inspiration everywhere,” Marisol confessed. “Books, retreats, conversations. But I still feel alone.”  

Javier smiled, recalling a teaching he’d once dismissed in youthful impatience. “Abraham-Hicks talks about Source. They say we can’t be separated from it, no matter how lost we feel.”

“How does one feel a presence you can’t see?” Marisol asked, folding her arms against a sudden breeze.

Before he could answer, Lucio arrived, his calm energy matching the mountain’s pace. He was neither technician nor academic, but his intuition was as precise as any piece of equipment. “We’re the receivers,” Lucio said, stepping close. “You’ve wired your thoughts to interference. Imagine instead that our inner being is a direct channel to Source—pure, alive, always on.”

Javier felt a thrill at the idea. He reached out and touched a wildflower growing between rocks. Its scent—earthy, sweet—seemed to speak in a language he understood. Suddenly, he perceived the truth: he was never separate from that boundless intelligence. It thrummed in every cell, in every breeze, in the distant roar of Quito’s traffic.

Marisol closed her eyes. The tension eased from her shoulders as she listened to the flower’s whisper, the volcanic stones’ steady heartbeat. Lucio placed a hand over her heart. “The signal is here,” he said. “Not miles below or high above. It’s right where you stand.”

Under Pichincha’s watch, they stood three, intimately connected—to each other and to Source. In that still moment on the mountainside, separation fell away, and they remembered what they had always known.
